user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of UtList_Create:
```c
UtListHead_t *UtList_Create(uint32 NumTags)
{
    struct ListAllocator
    {
        UtListHead_t Head;
        UtListNode_t Tags[];
    };
    struct ListAllocator *NewList;
    UtListNode_t *        TagHead;
    size_t                ActualSize;
    uint32                i;

    ActualSize = sizeof(struct ListAllocator) + (sizeof(UtListNode_t) * NumTags);
    NewList    = (struct ListAllocator *)malloc(ActualSize);

    memset(NewList, 0, ActualSize);

    NewList->Head.Tags         = NewList->Tags;
    NewList->Head.NumberOfTags = NumTags;

    for (i = 0; i < NumTags; ++i)
    {
        TagHead       = &NewList->Head.Tags[i];
        TagHead->Tag  = i;
        TagHead->Next = TagHead;
        TagHead->Prev = TagHead;
    }

    return &NewList->Head;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function UtList_Create:
typedef struct
{
    UtListNode_t *Tags;
    uint32        NumberOfTags;
} UtListHead_t
...
typedef struct UtListNodeTag
{
    struct UtListNodeTag *Next;
    struct UtListNodeTag *Prev;
    void *                Data;
    uint32                DataSize;
    uint32                Tag;
} UtListNode_t
...
void UtTest_EarlyInit(void)
{
    /*
     * Reset the test global variables, just in case.
     */
    memset(&UtAssert_Global, 0, sizeof(UtAssert_Global));
    UtAssert_Global.DataBasePtr = UtList_Create(UTASSERT_GROUP_MAX);
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: All other fragments in the provided code are declarations (local struct/type declarations, variable declarations) or comments and do not represent executable statements that could be statically unreachable. The listed fragments are the executable statements after the allocation: they should be investigated because if malloc() returns NULL these statements become effectively unreachable at runtime (and some will dereference NULL), which indicates missing error handling and potential runtime dead/unreachable behavior. No other statements in the function are executable or relevant to reachability analysis (the struct declaration and typedefs are definitions, not executable code).
